title: 106_s3063
content: The Act may be cited as the "Consumer Credit Score Disclosure Act of 2000" and includes definitions. Section 603 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include definitions related to credit scores for consumer credit applications secured by a dwelling. A credit score is defined as a numerical value derived from a statistical tool used to predict credit behaviors, excluding mortgage scores or ratings from automated underwriting systems. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to define key factors affecting credit scores for consumer credit applications secured by a dwelling, including factors beyond credit information like loan-to-value ratio and down payment amount. Key factors are listed in order of importance based on their effects on the credit score. Consumer reporting agencies are required to disclose credit scores under the Fair Credit Reporting Act. Consumer reporting agencies must disclose credit scores under the Fair Credit Reporting Act, including the consumer's current or most recent credit score, the range of possible credit scores, key factors affecting the score, the date the score was created, and the entity that provided the credit score. Consumer reporting agencies are required to disclose credit scores under the Fair Credit Reporting Act. The Act limits the provision of credit scores by consumer reporting agencies, stating that they are not compelled to develop or disclose a credit score if they do not distribute scores used in connection with credit secured by residential real property or develop credit scores that assist creditors in understanding general credit. The Fair Credit Reporting Act limits consumer reporting agencies from developing or disclosing credit scores that assist creditors in understanding general credit behavior or predicting future credit behavior. The Fair Credit Reporting Act restricts consumer reporting agencies from providing credit scores to consumers unless specifically requested. Consumers can request their credit file and a statement indicating they can also request and obtain a credit score. The credit score provided must be derived from a widely distributed credit scoring model used for credit extensions secured by a dwelling. The Fair Credit Reporting Act restricts consumer reporting agencies from providing credit scores to consumers unless specifically requested. Section 609(a)(1) of the Act is amended to include exceptions. Users of credit scores have duties as outlined in Section 4. In Section 615 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, users of credit scores are required to provide consumers with a copy of the credit score information used for credit extensions secured by a dwelling. Users of credit scores must provide consumers with a copy of the credit score information used for credit extensions secured by a dwelling, obtained from a third party. This includes a copy of the information described in section 609(a)(6) and a notice explaining credit scores and their sources. The user is not required to explain the information provided unless they developed it themselves. The user of a credit score must provide consumers with a copy of the information obtained from a consumer reporting agency or other person. They are not required to disclose any information other than the credit score or key factors, obtained after a transaction, or provide more than one disclosure per credit transaction. The user's liability is limited to providing the received information, with no responsibility for the content of the credit score. The Fair Credit Reporting Act limits liability for credit score information received from a consumer reporting agency. Section 615 is amended to include credit scores. SEC. 5. CONTRACTUAL LIABILITY. Amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to void any contract provision that prohibits the disclosure of a credit score. Users of credit scores are not liable for disclosing them. SEC. 6. RELATION TO STATE LAWS. SEC. 6. RELATION TO STATE LAWS. Amends the Fair Credit Reporting Act to include new subparagraphs related to the disclosure of credit scores by consumer reporting agencies and the duties of users of credit scores to disclose credit score information to consumers. SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will take effect 180 days after enactment.
